newsitem.title: USA: Clinton says U.S. mission accomplished in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Clinton says U.S. mission accomplished in Iraq.

text.p: President Bill Clinton said on Wednesday the U.S. mission in Iraq "has been achieved" by cruise missile attacks and Iraq has withdrawn its forces from a northern Kurdish area at least for the time being.

"Our mission has been achieved," Clinton told reporters called to the Oval Office. "... There has been a withdrawal of the (Iraqi) forces, a dispersal of the forces, but it's too soon to say that this is permanent or that further action will not be taken," Clinton said.

U.S. cruise missiles were fired at military targets in southern Iraq on Tuesday and Wednesday in retaliation for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's decision to send troops into a northern area occupied by Kurds who are under allied protection.

"The air strikes, the missile strikes, that were conducted over the last few days have been successful," Clinton said. "The targets are either destroyed or sufficiently damaged so that you can say that our mission has been achieved."
The cruise missile attacks enabled the allies to expand a no-fly zone bordering Kuwait and Saudi Arabia in the southern part of Iraq.

On a related issue, Clinton said U.S. forces had nothing to do with explosions and anti-aircraft fire reported in Baghdad on Wednesday. "They are not the result of any action that we have taken," he said.
